title: 108_hr3356
content: The Act may be cited as the "Joint Administrative Procedures Committee Act of 2003" or the "JAPC Act". It establishes a Joint Administrative Procedures Committee. The "Joint Administrative Procedures Committee Act of 2003" establishes a Joint Administrative Procedures Committee composed of 12 Members of the Senate and 12 Members of the House of Representatives, with not more than 7 members from the same political party. The committee is authorized to hold hearings, require witness attendance, and act during Congress sessions. The Joint Administrative Procedures Committee Act of 2003 establishes a committee with members from both the Senate and the House of Representatives. The committee has the authority to hold hearings, require witness attendance, administer oaths, and review existing major rules of Federal agencies. It can recommend legislative actions to amend or repeal laws and suggest changes to major rules. Additionally, the committee periodically reviews the regulatory plans of Federal agencies. The Joint Administrative Procedures Committee Act of 2003 establishes a committee with members from both the Senate and the House of Representatives. The committee has the authority to review regulatory plans of Federal agencies and may recommend legislative actions to amend or repeal laws and suggest changes to major rules. The committee may selectively review existing rules of Federal agencies and submit recommendations to the joint committee for further action. The Joint Administrative Procedures Committee Act of 2003 establishes a committee with members from both the Senate and the House of Representatives. The committee has the authority to review regulatory plans of Federal agencies and may recommend legislative actions to amend or repeal laws and suggest changes to major rules. Members of the committee report their recommendations to the appropriate standing committees of their respective Houses for further action. The Joint Administrative Procedures Committee Act of 2003 establishes a joint committee with members from both the Senate and the House of Representatives. Vacancies in the committee do not affect its functions, and members select a chairman and vice chairman at the beginning of each Congress. The chairmanship alternates between the Senate and the House, with the chairman and vice chairman chosen from their respective Houses. The committee may appoint and determine the compensation of its members. The joint committee may appoint staff and set their compensation. The House of Representatives will cover half of the committee's expenses, with payments approved by the chairman or vice chairman. Amounts will be spent according to House Administration regulations. SEC. 3. CONSIDERATION IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES AND THE SENATE. Section 802 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to allow any Member of the House to move to proceed to consideration of a joint resolution after the committee has reported. The motion is privileged, not debatable, and not subject to amendment. If agreed to, the House shall immediately proceed. The House shall immediately proceed to consideration of a joint resolution without intervening motion, order, or other business. Debate shall be limited to one hour, controlled by a proponent and an opponent. The previous question is ordered on the joint resolution for final passage, with one motion to recommit allowed. No motion to reconsider the vote on passage is permitted. CONGRESSIONAL REVIEW: The House shall proceed to consider a joint resolution without interruption, with debate limited to one hour. The joint resolution will be subject to a final passage vote with one motion to recommit allowed, and no motion to reconsider the vote on passage permitted. The Congressional Review process is amended to include the joint committee in the review of applicable rules. Within 30 days of receiving a report, the joint committee may recommend standing committees to report a joint resolution disapproving the rule. The Congressional Review process is amended to include the Joint Administrative Procedures Committee in the review of rules. The joint committee may recommend a resolution disapproving a rule within 30 days of receiving a report. The Act and its amendments will be effective on January 3, 2005.
